title: What your lunch says about you
intro: In this programme, Dan and Neil discuss the different lunch choices people make, and teaching you six items of vocabulary.
this_week_question: How long is the average lunch break in the UK?
a) An hour and a half
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: describes a short-term, low quality solution
designed to be practical rather than beautiful
to accept (an idea or belief) enthusiastically
to increase the number things you know about, usually by having new experiences
the good feeling of togetherness that a team can have

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English– the show that brings you an interesting topic, authentic listening practice and six items of incredibly useful vocabulary. I'm Dan…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. In this programme we’ll be discussing the lovely topic of lunch – and what our lunch choices say about us . So, Dan, what are you doing for lunch today?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Ah Neil, are you asking me to join you? I’d love to, thanks. There’s this great little Vietnamese place we have to check out, right next to the office if you just…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ah, actually – I was just asking to… open up today’s topic. Sorry. You see, I’ve brought a sandwich.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Oh, a sandwich. Again! How dull. Well, you’re not the only one – a survey from 2012 showed a third of Britons eat exactly the same thing for lunch – every day! And yes, it’s mostly sandwiches.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I had a curry yesterday.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, it’s almost lunchtime so we’d better get on with our question, which is: how long is the average lunch break in the UK? Is it:

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, I wish it was an hour and a half, but I’m pretty sure it must be c) 25 minutes

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, we’ll find out if you’re right… just before lunch! All this talk of lunch is actually making me feel a bit peckish .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Peckish is a great word isn’t it – it’s a slang word for being a bit hungry. Feeling peckish, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I am now. Now, about you and your sandwiches Neil. Two slices of bread with filling might be the most popular British lunch choice, but it didn’t use to be that way. Listen to food writer Bee Wilson. Which adjective does she use to describe sandwiches?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Bee Wilson, Author They were what you had in an emergency. They were what you had on a long train journey. It was a kind of makeshift lunch when you couldn’t get anything better.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: So – sandwiches had humble origins as makeshift meals. Makeshift describes something temporary and low quality – a solution you create when you can’t do anything better.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I can’t help feel this is all getting a little personal, Dan.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: There’s a sometimes very practical reason to eat a sandwich – like on a train. On a weekday in the office though, there’s no excuse.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: If you worked as hard as I did, Dan – you’d only have time for a sandwich!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Which is just what Bee Wilson was saying – we treat lunchtime as if it were an emergency. It says something about our attitude to work and food in the UK. Next, let’s hear from philosopher Julian Baggini with his view on eating the same thing every day.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And let’s teach one more word first – utilitarian . It describes something practical and useful, rather than attractive.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Julian Baggini, Philosopher What lunch says about us is that we’re still very much stuck in this kind of quite functional, you know, efficient, utilitarian attitude of how we should construct our daily lives; and that for all our embrace of this great food culture and everything, we haven’t managed to make that an everyday thing – it remains something for the special occasions.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So – he thinks we live in a world where we value being efficient – where we have a functional, utilitarian attitude to life.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Exactly, we’re aware of a great food culture, we embrace this culture – but only for special occasions.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes – let’s look at that word embrace . It normally means this… let me just…

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Oh Neil, I didn’t know you cared. Neil just hugged me, wrapped his arms around me, embraced me.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Just as we can embrace physical things and people – we can also embrace ideas.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Here’s an idea I embrace , Neil. We should all embrace new foods. Broaden our horizons .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: To broaden our horizons means 'to open our minds and experience new things'.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Let me broaden your horizons right now. Experts from Cornell University say it leads to better team spirit if colleagues eat together.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, I get the picture. I should ditch my sandwich and eat with you. In the name of team spirit – that is – getting on well with team members – having a feeling of belonging.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Finally. Vietnamese?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh yes, but not before you tell me the answer to today’s question. How long do Brits take for lunch?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well the answer was c) 25 minutes. That comes from a survey done by the BBC this year to find out about our modern dining habits.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: 25 minutes? It’s a crying shame, Dan. But before we have lunch ourselves, let’s run over the vocab one more time.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: First up we had peckish . It means 'hungry – just a little hungry'. I’m feeling rather peckish at the moment, you?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I think I’ve gone beyond peckish , Dan. Roll on lunch. Next?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: We had makeshift – which describes a temporary or low quality solution. For example, last week my team’s goalkeeper was sick, so I had to replace him as a makeshift goalie.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Or, another example – when I was a student I used the steel bin in my room as a makeshift drum.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I’m sure the neighbours loved that. Now what about this word utilitarian ? In the context we used it, it means 'simple and functional, rather than beautiful'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Do you think it would be fair to describe your polo shirt as utilitarian ?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I prefer classic and timeless. Please.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But enough of all this banter. You know, I believe we should all just get along.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Oh, are you going to hug me again? To embrace me?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Not this time, let’s stick with the metaphorical meaning – 'to accept a new belief or idea'.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: For example, I wasn’t sure about the new website design, but now I fully embrace it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Very nice. And I embrace your suggestion that colleagues should eat together.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: It looks like you’ve broadened your horizons .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, when I taught English in Spain, Japan, Poland and the Czech Republic, it really broadened my horizons and taught me about new ways of life. How about you?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes, they say travel broadens the mind – it certainly broadened my horizons too.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Even better – why don’t we go travelling together – with the whole Learning English team?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yeah! That would be wonderful for team spirit –the good feeling of being together. Maybe to Cambodia?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It certainly would. And that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon, after our delicious lunch!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And we are on social media too. Make sure to visit our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
